author: NoahNeedleman
content:
Ok Long Post alert, but touches on a few things we harp on around here. 

So my little bro is in town- we made dinner for one of his oldest friends who just moved to town with his wife. He’s a fantastic mandolin player and his wife is a singer/songwriter. 

Of course I did the ol’ studio walk through, listening to all the tunes on the ear calibration playlist, then let them play some of their own favs. Of course they’re blown away and have never heard music like this etc. 

But to drive the point home I show them a song @Rollmottle and I turned around in just over 24 hours. “The reason for the speakers & treatment etc is so we can make decisions quickly blah blah blah.”  I pull up the session and we listen through and they’re loving it- but I’m noticing it doesn’t have the 3D thing that all the other music we’ve been listening to has. 

Then I show them the mastered version. An mp3. It’s louder and better sounding and all, until the first BGV stack hits… then it’s IMMERSIVE. We listened to the whole thing again just to enjoy the magic and notice all the ways the master improved it. So far beyond zapping resonances and making it loud, @Rollmottle made it sound… important. Made *me* sound like a good mixer. 

It was heavier lifting for him cause I didn’t have the benefit of time for fresh ears or to detail the vocal the way I normally would. Also had the good fortune of having @Ross Fortune on speed dial and on GMT to give it a listen at 5am PST. 

I’d you’re curious, or dubious, I’ll DM files so you can hear what I’m talking about. 

TL;DR: monitoring matters, fresh perspective matters. Don’t produce mix *and* master your own shit.

author: Slow Hand
content:
Pretty damn frequently. Producers moreso than mixers.

When I find a record that resonates with me I'm very full-immersion and I'll devour as much of their adjacent body of work as I can. I'll start scrutinizing the record credits and pulling on threads as I see them. I really try to fill in the context around the record by identifying all collaborators, timelines, interviews they gave around that time, published works, etc. I've got a huge appetite for that thing.

I really love reading books written by producers. The more old school the better. Phil Ramone's *Making Records* is a great one. That guy is a class act. Quincy Jones has both an autobiography *and* a book specifically on producing. The latter is a great no-shortcuts look at what it takes to be great. I enjoyed Daniel Lanois' *Soul Mining*, since he's got a very thoughtful immersive way of making records and working with artists that I appreciate.

author: peterlabberton
content:
Yeah… this is just me sharing my opinion, not trying to shit on anyone else’s: I am thoroughly uninterested in spatial/atmos. I’ve been able to listen in a few really swanky/certified rooms, to tracks that other more atmos-inclined folks were really pumped about, and I just thought it was gimmicky and—to my taste!—kinda lame. Not for any technical reason (though I have issues there as well), I just don’t care if a shaker sounds like it’s behind me and to the left or I’m *fully* enveloped in a reverb or whatever.

If I have to wrap my head around it to stay relevant, I’m fairly confident I can give my self a crash course—and if someone asked me to do an atmos mix and paid for the studio, then sure! But short of that… 🤷🏻‍♂️

author: Slow Hand
content:
Stereo. I tried out some Atmos headphone mixes at an Apple store kiosk a while ago because I was curious. I can't say that it had much of an effect on me. Maybe I need to live with them for longer and get used to it.

Last week was the first time that I was able to sit in front of an Atmos setup that was meant for music (aka: not in a movie theater) and really get the full musical experience. In fact, I got to sit in front of *three* different Atmos rigs in three different (treated) rooms that evening and two of them were undoubtedly set up as good as they could have possibly been (One was a PMC showroom and the other built and tuned with their input). While the speakers themselves were impressive and very capable, the actual experience felt pretty disjointed. There was a pronounced feeling of phasi-ness that I didn't like.

It was great hearing these records on a rig that probably cost $250k, but my big takeaway was that they felt disjointed and odd. Even when sitting in the sweet spot.

Perhaps my opinion will change with more exposure, but I'm not yet convinced that it's worth the time and effort. I will add, though, that half the mixes we heard were up-mixed from old stereo recordings with minimal track counts and only two of them were modern productions.

author: Nomograph Mastering
content:
Man, this is a huge topic. And would be hard to address without touching on the political. My lunch break is over but again my intuition is to ask why this might be the case and I think a few factors might contribute 

- older generations grew up in a “keep your head down” world, whereas younger grew up with a more social “if you see something say something” atmosphere. Ostensibly a good thing …

- Social media rewards performance value judgements … “Mr Y is a bad guy” 

- The internet and social media has made younger generations vulnerable to manipulation by interests who wish to control the narrative

author: Adam Thein
content:
Damn.

So I just realized i've had Apple Music set to Dolby Atmos Automatic for god knows how long and it has been automatically detecting my audio interface as a multi-channel interface and turning on Atmos mixes for me that I've been listening to in stereo and they are 100% not the correct stereo mix.  Just turned Dolby Atmos to OFF and now I feel like a fool.

Thought I'd share here and encourage everyone to make sure they have that setting off if they aren't using Airpods or a legit Atmos setup.  I've been referencing some stuff that absolutely didn't sound right.

author: LAPhill
content: I know you're joking, but what is the point of spatial audio? To immerse the listener in a world of music. To create a 3D experience. Why? We can go outside and listen to a band in a room and hear reflections all around us. But there is a chance to go deeper with spatial audio, to create something hyper-real, as much of record making has always been. Every new technology has the opportunity to enhance or detract from our experiences, and we have to meet them where they are. Maybe Atmos ain't it, but as someone who spends a lot of time in surround.. there is a feeling to immersing yourself in sound that isn't going to come from two speakers. So yes.. mixing in Atmos can very much be a part of steering the ship.

author: Iwan Morgan
content: Do you mean that headphones lack feel, so it’s difficult to get the emotion in the work while mixing? I think it’s a different kind of feel. I’ll look for the chest/bass check when listening on speakers but I want to be transported by the atmosphere and connection when listening on headphones. Some of the most formative experiences for me were listening via headphones and I try and remember those fomative feelings when checking on headphones - cassette dubs of Fabio and Grooverider on radio 1 back in the day, Spike’s mixes of Massive Attack and Mad Professor versions, my dad’s vinyl of Dark Side of the Moon etc etc

author: karlemilhald
content: Exactly. There are a lot of songs that have a lot of problems. Bob Marley - Is This Love sounds beautiful to me, but that seems to be an exception (and it still gets at bit of that washy sound). i would imagine these mixes are mixed for a proper Atmos setup, but how many of people listening are really gonna have that? I believe in the Atmos format for headphones for that reason. But i think it would require mixing engineers to mix with headphones in mind if that washy/roomy sound should disappear

author: peterlabberton
content:
Yeah man, I love that part of town. And it’s certainly pretty wild how saturated those neighborhoods are with music folks! Super exciting to be immersed in all that every day. Covid/delta/etc. makes everything pretty uncertain to me but my plan is definitely to still hang in that part of LA pretty frequently. We shall see…

I think my perspective of what I wanted shifted a bit when I subbed in for @cian riordan working for St. Vincent—Annie’s studio feels pretty secluded and I loved that atmosphere. I started looking for rentals in some of the canyons and found great stuff but nothing I felt like I could afford without having an absolute panic attack every month. And then I saw what is now my studio room pop up in a photo on Craigslist and here we are!

author: spectrummasters
content: In nature birds go quiet when there are predators close . These are signals our auditory system evolved to pick up on . It’s core to our experience as animals to provide ourselves with these signals for example . So to hear you bring evolutionary biology into the discussions around atmos is so good man . People need to know this stuff it’s vital to our quality of life experience . In my kitchen I alternate smooth fm (70s/80s classics for the sonics ) or birdsong , for the stress relief . I cannot recommend leaving birdsong on for a few hours in your home enough

author: spectrummasters

Nature )…..and hearing you bring this sort of thing into the atmos conversation is actually a relief imo ruairi . Keep going man !!!

author: andrew_yv
content:
An interesting side note re: the psychoacoustic HRTF binaural sound localization discussion from yesterday’s live with @Nomograph Mastering :

I can’t find my source right now but if/when I do I will link it, anyways… A study was conducted wherein moulds were cast of several people’s pinnae (outer ears), these were placed on dummy heads with microphones inside the ‘ear canals’ and recordings were made through each of sound coming from a variety of locations. Some of the subjects were audio professionals and some were lay people.
When the subjects listened back to these recordings, there was significant variance in their ability to localize the sound sources. If I remember correctly, they were generally better at listening through their own pinnae than others were, and audio professionals were a bit better at sound localization in general, particularly in the traditional stereo field. However, the really interesting finding was that there were some pinnae that were universally better or worse. People actually had improved localization through someone else’s pinnae than their own, implying that although we are adapted to our own pinnae, there are material differences that make some better than others for localization of sound.
This is all from memory of reading something a few months ago, so I apologize if there are details that aren’t 100% accurate, but I assure you that the surprising bit is correct!

HRTF-based binaural mixes are not exactly the same thing as dummy head recordings, but I wonder if, in the creation of the aforementioned “baller individual HRTF’s” there might be a place for some optimization beyond the exact copying of an individual’s unique acoustic properties.

author: Matthew The Cooke🎄🎅🏻
content:
I find it really interesting that for instance in music streaming there are various streaming platforms that pretty much do exactly the same thing (provide all, or most of recorded music at a cost). There might be slight discrepancies (spotify not having Joni Mitchell/Neil Young catalogue until recently) but they offer essentially exactly the same product so they have to convince consumers from a different perspective („we pay artists more, we sound better, we have spatial audio etc.“) 
And on the other end of the spectrum you have the complete shitshow that is streaming movies/series on demand where you have to have like 5 different subscriptions bankrupting you just so you can watch your favourite movies. It‘s interesting how those two offer basically the same thing (access to entertainment on demand) but have developed drastically different

author: andrew_yv
content:
Sony set me up with it for Mike’s BH room in both stereo and atmos. It’s the first spatialization tech that has impressed me. Not sure how quickly I would reach for it in stereo, but I can confidently pre-mix things in atmos with it, and with some loss of detail, it really does sound like *those speakers in that room through my ears*

Process is pretty cool and elegant. They put electret mics in your ears, record IR sweeps of each speaker in your room through them, then put headphones on, record IR sweeps of those, then have some sort of sum/difference algo that translates it all.

When you get measured, go for relatively high SPL sweeps. We tried it at a few different levels and at lower levels, the result was pretty unimpressive. You can also go too high and distort, but worth trying a couple times if they’re game, which I’m 100% sure they will be for you

They sent a bunch of songs that were expected to be released, some weren’t and all got mixed. Manny charged for all, of course. Line items for each were that per song mixing rate, the studio fee which was per song, and atmos

author: hank01564
content: I think it was more of a communication issue more than anything - client shouldn’t have sent songs until tracklist was finalized and for sure shouldn’t have allowed him to be the atmos mixer if their budget was already suffering. And I’m not sure if charging a “studio fee” is standard for the top dogs but that one caught them by surprise and it was pretty substantial hit

Apple Music currently accounts for 30% of streaming in the US, it was about 10-15% about 5 years back. ASAF is also very much full steam ahead in development so who knows. tl;dr not DOA, perhaps plateaued.

author: Gerhard Westphalen
content: In my studio I have almost 10 kW of class D amps. Last I checked my entire studio idled at around 4 amps and with the system going full throttle with atmos it was hitting around 6 amps. That would be around 700 W. When I've had power outages I have had the breaker trip when power comes back on from everything trying to power on at the same time. No clue how much that would theoretically need but if you don't try to turn everything on at the same time, a 1800 W generator should be plenty for most set ups
